projects.title: ODE TO THE SEA LAMPREY
projects.description:
For the Zeeprik Genootschap - Dutch Sea Lamprey Society I organized another event dedicated to the much-maligned sea lamprey - with a small exhibition introducing the lamprey and an exhibition of artwork inspired by the lamprey and the phenomenon of the living fossil; a lecture 'The Family of Lampreys in The Netherlands'; a gastronomic dinner.

Sunday April 12th 2015. At TAAK - international platform for innovative art. Amsterdam.

For the dishes of the dinner titled 'Consumed by Immortals' socalled living fossils - including, gingko, algae, jelly fish - will be main ingredient, with sea lamprey from French Aquitaine the 'pièce de résistance'. It is the first time for more than 100 years fresh sea lamprey will be served in the Netherlands. 

With its evolutionary history going back 550 million years, the sea lamprey together with the hagfish are striking representations of the phenomenon of the living fossil, and the only survivors of the Jawless fish.

Sea lamprey larvae lives in freshwater. Reaching maturity they transform dramatically into a one meter long, eellike creature which migrates to sea to hunt fish like salmon or cod. With its round mouth armored with circles of teeth the lamprey bites in the flesh of its prey sucking blood. After a period of several years living in sea the lamprey returns to the freshwater rivers to spawn.

In Europe until 1945, sea lamprey was found in abundance and eaten as tasty food fit for kings. After the war the lamprey almost disappeared, mainly because of water constructions obstructing the trek of the lamprey or because of water pollution.

Only in northern Portugal, northern Spain and French Aquitaine the lamprey is still caught and eaten as a tasty culinary heritage. And only French Aquitaine harbors a healthy population of sea lamprey, thanks to the joint efforts of chefs, local fishermen and conservationists which transformed since 20 years the rivers again into the lamprey habitat they once were.

projects.title: Maastrichtian Man invites…   An archaeo-gastronomical exploration where Archaeology, Art and Deep History of the City of Maastricht collide
projects.description:
The archaeology of the Meuse region in around the city of Maastricht is one of the most interesting in the Low Countries, especially the archaeology of the region’s deep history, covering a period of 500,000 years. 

This region’s deep archaeological history has its starting point 500,000 years old artifacts, most probably made by Heidelberg Man, revealed at a quarry near Kesselt, a hamlet in Flanders, only two kilometre away from Maastricht. 
Artifacts and other remains indicating Neanderthals presence were found at several locations - in the municipality itself or not far away - dated between 250,000 - 55,000 years ago. 
The first farmers of the Low Countries, the Lineair Bandceramic Culture (LBK), arrived in this region 7,300 years ago, after a trek that initially started in Anatolia.
For the Celtic tribe of the Eburones the Sint Pieterberg may have been on of their centers from about 500 BC, until they were annihilated by Caesar’s legions in 54 BC. 

This archaeo-gastronomical exploration Maastrichtian Man Invites… asks you to taste the deep history of the region. You will break bread with the ancient Maastricht people: Heidelberg Man, Neanderthal Man, Lineair Bandceramic Farmer and Celtic Eburone, eating the food they could have eaten.

projects.title: Het Zeeprik Genootschap - Confrérie hollandaise de la Lamproie de mer - Dutch Sealamprey Society
projects.description:
Het Zeeprik Genootschap (2010): officiële introductie 16 juni 2013, Blankenstraat 115 A'dam, 16.00.

Expositie: “De Zeeprik: Levend Fossiel, Kunstzinnige Inspiratiebron en Culinair Erfgoed”; 
Inschrijving tot Genootschapslid; 
‘Immortellenbuffet’ – 'Proef' van levende fossielen.

Het Zeeprik Genootschap tracht de geheimen van de zeeprik te doorgronden door het bevorderen van het onderzoek en de kennis van de families van de prik en de slijmprik, markante representanten van het fenomeen ‘levend fossiel’. 

Het Genootschap presenteert informatie over beide families - biologie, natuurlijke historie, evolutionaire geschiedenis, levenswijze en gedrag, betekenis voor de mens. 

Het Genootschap promoot tevens het fenomeen 'levend fossiel' als poëtische inspiratiebron waarmee het aloude thema van Mens & Tijd van nieuwe inhoud en van nieuwe beelden kan worden voorzien.

De zeeprikken zijn samen met de slijmprikken de enige overlevende van de 500 miljoen jaar oude Kaaklozen.  De priklarve leeft als bodemfilteraar in zoetwater om bij het volwassen worden te veranderen in één meter lange, aalachtige rover die naar zee trekt en jaagt op vissen. Met zijn getande bek zet de prik zich vast in zijn prooi en zuigt deze leeg. Om te paaien keert het dier terug naar zoetwater, waarna het sterft. De prikkenstand is door milieuvervuiling sterk bedreigd, tot ver in de 20e eeuw was de prik algemeen en gold hij als zeer smakelijk voedsel. In Frans Aquitanië is, dankzij de inzet van chefs, vissers en natuurbeschermers de zeeprik teruggekeerd.

Wat is een levend fossiel? Steven Stanley ‘Levende fossielen zijn soorten die tot de recente biota behoren en die anatomisch veel lijken - grenzend aan identiek zijn - op een soort die ontstond aan het beginpunt van de evolutionaire lijn van de groep waar het organisme toebehoort.’ G.G. Simpson: ‘Levende fossielen zijn organismen waarvan het evolutionair proces traag verloopt of zelfs stil staat.’

profile_positions.company: Eating<TIME - The Archaeology and the Art of Food and Eating
profile_positions.description:
Laboratory for the Senses and the Mind, the Heart and the Soul

MISSION STATEMENT: Use all approaches to seek clues from all relevant disciplines, to investigate and to explore Food and Eating as Driving Force in the Process of Making Us Human

The explorations and presentations of Eating<TIME demonstrate the particular qualities of the food factor when tracing Man and his (un)doing.

Archeology: from the Greek ‘arche’ = origin, source; and from the greek ‘logy’ = the study of.

Humans cook probably since two million years ago. However for humans of the modern world food is the great unknown.

The discovery of cooking two million years ago was a monumental event in the history of mankind – and in the history of the world. It led to physiological and anatomical adaptions, transforming a proto-human into a human. It also brought a mental and spiritual transformation, a new perception of the world and of human’s place in it. With fire and cooking humans were able to humanize the world. Cooking was the first artform. Cooking shaped thinking – and thinking shaped cooking.

The notion that the discovery of fire and the use of cooking also brought a new perception of the world has important consequences for the theories regarding what makes us human – with fire and cooking humans were given instruments in hand to shape his own evolution and his own fate, and in doing so managed themselves into a problematic relationship with nature - of which we will reap, and are reaping, the bitter fruit.

"Eating is inseparable from the behaviour and biology of the human species and from the adaptions that humans have made to the conditions of the existence of the planet". P. Farb & G.Armelagos: "Consuming Passions, the Anthropology of Eating".
